Directions.1: Wash, peel, and core quinces, reserving cores and peels. Coarsely chop flesh and transfer fruit to a large pan. Wrap cores and peels in cheesecloth, tie bag with kitchen string, and add it to the pan. (The peels contain most of fruit's pectin, which contributes to the firmness of quince paste.)

Directions.2: Pour in enough water to cover quinces and boil, half-covered, for 30 to 40 minutes or until fruit is very soft. Remove bag of peels and pass quince flesh through a sieve or food mill. (For best results, don't use a food processor as it will result in too fine a texture.) You should have about 2 1/2 pounds of fruit pulp.

Directions.3: Transfer quince pulp to a saucepan and add sugar (ideally, you should add the same amount of sugar, by weight, as fruit pulp). Cook and stir over low heat until sugar is dissolved. Continue cooking for about 1 1/2 hours, stirring frequently with a wooden spoon, until paste becomes very thick and has a deep orange color. Draw the wooden spoon along the bottom of the saucepan: it should leave a trail and quince mixture will stick to the spoon.

Directions.4: Lightly grease a 9x13-inch baking dish or line it with greased parchment paper. Transfer quince paste to the baking dish, spreading it about 1 1/2-inch thick. Smooth the top and allow it to cool.

Directions.5: Dry paste on your lowest oven setting, no more than 125 degrees F (52 degrees C), for about 1 1/2 hours. Allow quince paste to cool completely before slicing. (In Europe, the traditional method of drying quince paste is to leave it in a cupboard for about 7 days. The remaining juices will continue to evaporate and render a drier paste.)

Directions.6: Store quince paste in an airtight container in the refrigerator; the color will deepen with age.
